snippet: The Bronx district attorney had argued that a gang met the somewhat vague definition of “terror” in the state statute because it sought to intimidate or coerce an entire population.
abstract: New York State Court of Appeals rules that the Bronx district attorney’s office erred in trying to use a state terrorism charge to prosecute street gangs; decision overturns  2007 conviction of Edgar Morales, admitted Bronx gang member, who was involved in gang shooting in 2002 that left a 10-year-old girl dead; case against Morales was built around belief that gang intimidation of community members loosely fit definitions of terrorism in state statutes.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx district attorney had argued that a gang met the somewhat vague definition of “terror” in the state statute because it sought to intimidate or coerce an entire population.

headline.seo: New York State’s Highest Court Rules Gang Crime Falls Short of Terrorism
headline.main: Court Rules Gang Crime Falls Short of Terrorism
headline.print_headline: Court Rules Gang Crime Falls Short Of Terrorism
